title.narrative: Fra barn til borger - holistiske tilgange til barnebeskyttelse i Xinjiang. 2. fase , engagement

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: 4. To advocate with the government to strengthen social and educational service for child development

description.narrative: Assessment of results: The Education Bureau and All China Women’s Federation have recognised the importance of children’s holistic development for better life, and the crucial importance of schools to support children’s healthy developments. They have produced official endorsements and asked all village level schools to use the curriculum in their weekly schedule. As the life skill concept was very new to the partners, their understanding and acceptance had the first priority, while the intervention through curriculum and improvement of children’s life skills was rolled afterwards. Additionally, the project was advocated to regional level partners through different meetings to make a bigger impact. At the same time, the intervention was also recognised by other provincial offices.

title.narrative: 4. To advocate with the government to strengthen social and educational service for child development

description.narrative: Assessment of results: The Education Bureau and All China Women’s Federation have recognised the importance of children’s holistic development for better life, and the crucial importance of schools to support children’s healthy developments. They have produced official endorsements and asked all village level schools to use the curriculum in their weekly schedule. As the life skill concept was very new to the partners, their understanding and acceptance had the first priority, while the intervention through curriculum and improvement of children’s life skills was rolled afterwards. Additionally, the project was advocated to regional level partners through different meetings to make a bigger impact. At the same time, the intervention was also recognised by other provincial offices.

comment.narrative: Concrete evidence from project sites will be used to encourage local education authorities to mainstream life skills education in primary schools. As the life skills curriculum is best taught using child-centred, participatory teaching methodologies, advocating for a broad adoption of the life skills curriculum will help introduce these teaching methodologies. Local authorities in Korla and Hotan will be aimed to roll out life skills education in all schools under their administration beyond the existing project schools. The regional education bureau will be involved at strategic moments during the project to encourage wider adoption at the regional level, and media will be used to widely publicise project success stories.

title.narrative: 2. To incorporate life skills curriculum in basic education

description.narrative: Assessment of results: The curriculum on life skills created an opportunity for children to learn effectively by attending one or two life skills sessions every week. The children are highly satisfied with the life skills courses, and teachers and parents are highly satisfied with training for teachers and parents. All the ten major life skills have been strengthened among the students, problem behaviours of students have reduced, and the interactive relationship among students, teachers and parents have improved. Schools have implemented a more robust management to enhance students’ safety and teachers’ behaviours and reporting systems have been set up. Students, teachers and parents have become more actively involved in school management, including awareness on positive discipline, violence, bullying and abuse.

title.narrative: 2. To incorporate life skills curriculum in basic education

description.narrative: Assessment of results: The curriculum on life skills created an opportunity for children to learn effectively by attending one or two life skills sessions every week. The children are highly satisfied with the life skills courses, and teachers and parents are highly satisfied with training for teachers and parents. All the ten major life skills have been strengthened among the students, problem behaviours of students have reduced, and the interactive relationship among students, teachers and parents have improved. Schools have implemented a more robust management to enhance students’ safety and teachers’ behaviours and reporting systems have been set up. Students, teachers and parents have become more actively involved in school management, including awareness on positive discipline, violence, bullying and abuse.

comment.narrative: Incorporating the life skills curriculum will enable children to acquire skills beyond the national unified school curriculum and empower them with additional skills to use later in life. A life skills curriculum will be introduced in primary schools by cooperating with education research centres, teachers and children to set up a working group and identify appropriate topics that the curriculum will deal with. Following the model of the previous life skills project, a set of life skills curriculum targeting different age groups will be developed.

title.narrative: 3. To create a safe, protective and inclusive environment for children in their community

description.narrative: Assessment of results: The parents have played a very important role in family parenting and their contribution has made the community more harmonious. The project team developed six sessions on positive parenting training, including how to encourage children to cooperate with adults, the methods instead of punishment, to teach children how to be independent etc. The sessions have been very useful for parents who know very little about positive parenting. The parent gained a sound understanding of education notions, and their educational and parenting behaviours have been improved to some extent. Parent-children relationships have improved and many parents have achieved personal development in the project.

title.narrative: 3. To create a safe, protective and inclusive environment for children in their community

description.narrative: Assessment of results: The parents have played a very important role in family parenting and their contribution has made the community more harmonious. The project team developed six sessions on positive parenting training, including how to encourage children to cooperate with adults, the methods instead of punishment, to teach children how to be independent etc. The sessions have been very useful for parents who know very little about positive parenting. The parent gained a sound understanding of education notions, and their educational and parenting behaviours have been improved to some extent. Parent-children relationships have improved and many parents have achieved personal development in the project.

comment.narrative: Children should be developing in a safe and protective environment inside the schools and at home, which recognises the value of education. A coherent and consistent education model for children beyond school will be created, which fosters their participation, ensures that their voices are heard and their physical and mental well-being are protected by involving parents and the communities.

title.narrative: 1. To improve the quality of compulsory education through building the capacity of teachers on child-centred methodology

description.narrative: Assessment of results: This component has introduced a new perspective on children’s learning and development. Local Education Authorities have been closely involved in developing a culturally appropriate approach to academic learning as well as other skills for life skills education based on global research on children’s development, long-term learning and broader cognitive, social and emotional functioning. Teachers not only gained a sound understanding of the child-centred teaching notion, but also applied the notion and certain practices in their teaching activities. The overall professional quality of teachers has been enhanced and life skills teaching are integrated in academic lessons. This is i.e. clear in the creativity in lesson planning, participation of children and better understanding of children’s different learning styles.

title.narrative: 1. To improve the quality of compulsory education through building the capacity of teachers on child-centred methodology

description.narrative: Assessment of results: This component has introduced a new perspective on children’s learning and development. Local Education Authorities have been closely involved in developing a culturally appropriate approach to academic learning as well as other skills for life skills education based on global research on children’s development, long-term learning and broader cognitive, social and emotional functioning. Teachers not only gained a sound understanding of the child-centred teaching notion, but also applied the notion and certain practices in their teaching activities. The overall professional quality of teachers has been enhanced and life skills teaching are integrated in academic lessons. This is i.e. clear in the creativity in lesson planning, participation of children and better understanding of children’s different learning styles.

comment.narrative: Teaching quality in primary schools for children aged 6-12 years old will be improved by delivering systematic and intense teacher training based on Save the Children’s Quality Learning Environment.

title.narrative: 1.1. 320 primary school teachers participated in training to integrate child-centred methods into their teaching
1.1. 320 primary school teachers participated in training to integrate child-centred methods into their teaching

comment.narrative: 1) 320 teachers trained on child-centred teaching methodologies, and 2) two school based teaching contests and activities held each year

title.narrative: 3.1. Establish parents supporting network and train them to help them involve in school development plan and facilitate activities
3.1. Establish parents supporting network and train them to help them involve in school development plan and facilitate activities

comment.narrative: 1) 4 parents committee established, 2) 240 parents trained on positive discipline, child participation, child rights and importance of education, 3) 80 parents peer educators trained, 4) 2 community based activities held each year/site, and 5) school development plan produced in 6 schools

title.narrative: 1.2. 120 teachers providing necessary support to other teachers in their project schools
1.2. 120 teachers providing necessary support to other teachers in their project schools

comment.narrative: 1) 40 trainers trained, 2) 120 support teachers trained on supporting skills as child centred teaching methods, planning and monitoring to provide necessary support to other teachers, 3) Support teachers' supporting plan carried out each semester, and 4) Two support teachers forum held both in Yining and Hetian.

title.narrative: 2.2. Life skills curriculum is in use within the weekly schedule in at least 10 classes (of different grades) in each school
2.2. Life skills curriculum is in use within the weekly schedule in at least 10 classes (of different grades) in each school

comment.narrative: 1) 60 teachers trained on implementing life skills curriculum, 2) 100 student peer educators trained, and 3) life skills curriculum forum held

title.narrative: 2.1. Life skills curriculum developed
2.1. Life skills curriculum developed

comment.narrative: 1) Life skill curriculum development team established, 2) two trainings delivered to the team, and 3) 20 school teachers trained on curriculum (its components, scope and M&E tool)

title.narrative: 3.2. 19 micro projects organised in community and schools with involvement of parents
3.2. 19 micro projects organised in community and schools with involvement of parents

comment.narrative: 1) Needs assessment conducted and 2) micro project proposals made out

title.narrative: 4.2. Organise experience sharing and wrap up meeting to share project results, best practices and benefits of child-centred teaching methodologies and life skill curriculum
4.2. Organise experience sharing and wrap up meeting to share project results, best practices and benefits of child-centred teaching methodologies and life skill curriculum

comment.narrative: 1) One exchange visit per year between project sites in year 2 and 3, and 2) two regional network meetings

title.narrative: 4.1. At least 45 Education Bureau officials and teachers actively participate in shared learning through 3-5 day study tours to inner China
4.1. At least 45 Education Bureau officials and teachers actively participate in shared learning through 3-5 day study tours to inner China

comment.narrative: 1) Three study tours organised within China, 2) partner capacitybuilding training on project management, M&E, CRC, modern pedagogy, life skills concept and scope, and 3) kick-off planning meetings

title.narrative: 1.3. Teaching support materials available in all project schools
